What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course was a wonderful introduction to the canonical themes and works in the field. The personal classroom setup was conducive to asking questions and engaging in interesting discussions.

I gained extensive knowledge on a host of themes in the South Asian, especially Indian, context such as colonial legacies, language politics, party politics, communal conflicts, civil-military relations, poverty and inequality, service delivery and migration.

I learned a great deal about South Asian politics, particularly during the first few decades after India and Pakistan gained independence. I engaged more deeply with issues of identity, ethnicity, and nationalism than I had done in the past. Further, I became more familiar with some of the cutting edge work on public goods provision and governance in South Asia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: A course especially designed for advanced readings on the topic was a wonderful way to harness our background knowledge to expand our horizons on a wide range of topics The small classroom setting allowed for engaging conversations. The readings were a great mix of the classical and the newest works in the field. Weaknesses: Some more concrete guidelines about what is expected out of the final paper would have been helpful.

Strengths of the course: (i) As mentioned earlier, it covers a range of themes such as colonial legacies, party politics, service delivery, communal conflicts and hence, very valuable for anyone keen on specializing in the South Asian region; (ii) The readings are a really good mix from various disciplines: political science, economics, history and anthropology; (iii) It is taught by Prof. Wilkinson who is extremely knowledgeable about the South Asian context. Can't think of any weakness of this course!

Strengths: great smattering of readings from a wide range of time periods; course encouraged us to think about potential avenues for future research Weaknesses: could have incorporated more contemporary political science literature on Pakistan

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. Important course for future scholars of South Asia.
Yes, I would certainly recommend this course to a student who is planning to specialize in the South Asian region.
Yes, it's a terrific way to become acclimated to political science scholarship on South Asia and think about potential future avenues of research on the region.
